questions.text: The specialized group of mesenchymal cells that aggregate to form blood islands is called:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The mesenchymal stem cells that aggregate to form blood islands are Angioblasts.
  • These angioblasts arise from Hemangioblasts during a process called 'Vasculogenesis.'
  • Angioblasts form angiogenic cell clusters, which form blood islands centrally and primitive blood vessels peripherally.
  • Early angiogenesis occurs in the chorion, yolk sac & connecting stalk, but involves only mesodermal cells.

Explanation of Other Options:
Mesangioblasts(Option A): These are mesodermal stem cells involved in skeletal muscle and connective tissue development, not blood vessel formation.

Fibroblasts(Option C): These are connective tissue cells that produce collagen and extracellular matrix, not involved in blood or vessel formation.

Yolk sac endoderm(Option D): provides paracrine support but does not directly form blood islands, which arise from mesoderm-derived cells.

choices.text: It disappears partially and forms the transverse pericardial sinus
It disappears completely and forms the oblique pericardial sinus
It persists and contributes to the fibrous pericardium
It persists and becomes the endocardium

questions.text: What is the fate of the dorsal mesocardium during cardiac development?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Early in heart development, following head folding, the heart tube is suspended within the pericardial cavity by the dorsal mesocardium.
  • As the heart folds on itself so that the intake and outflow tracts come together, the dorsal mesocardium ruptures.
  • This forms the transverse pericardial sinus behind the great arteries.

Explanation of Other Options:

It disappears completely and forms the oblique pericardial sinus(Option B): The oblique sinus is formed by the reflection of serous pericardium around the pulmonary veins and vena cavae, not from the dorsal mesocardium.

It persists and contributes to the fibrous pericardium(Option C): The fibrous pericardium arises from somatic mesoderm, not the dorsal mesocardium.

It persists and becomes the endocardium(Option D): The endocardium forms from endocardial tubes derived from splanchnic mesoderm, not from the dorsal mesocardium.

choices.text: Splanchnic mesoderm in the wall of the yolk sac

questions.text: By 13-14 days of development, angiogenic cell clusters have differentiated in the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Angiogenic cell clusters develop in all of these areas, giving rise to the cardiovascular system in the embryo.
  • Within the embryo, the angiogenic cell clusters are found in the horseshoe-shaped region beneath the intraembryonic coelom.
  • Cranial to the prochordal plate lies the cardiogenic region, part of this larger area.
  • Blood islands and angiogenic clusters first form in the extraembryonic mesoderm of the chorion, connecting stalk, and yolk sac around day 13-14. (Option A)
  • The yolk sac wall (splanchnic mesoderm side) is one of the first sites where angiogenic cell clusters and blood islands appear. (Option B)
  • Around this time, angiogenic clusters also begin to appear in the cardiogenic mesoderm, contributing to the formation of the heart tubes. (Option C)

questions.text: The most superior part of the inferior vena cava is derived from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The vitelline veins, as they pass through the developing liver, break up into hepatic sinusoids. When the left sinus horn regresses, blood is shunted from the left vitelline vein to the right, causing the right vein to enlarge and ultimately form the posthepatic portion of the inferior vena cava.

Explanation of Other Options:

Left Vitelline Vein(Option A): The left vitelline vein mostly regresses during development; remnants may contribute to hepatic sinusoids.

Right Umbilical Vein(Option C): The right umbilical vein regresses early in development, completely disappearing by around the 7th week.

Left Umbilical Vein(Option D): This is the only umbilical vein that persists temporarily and becomes connected to the ductus venosus, which shunts oxygenated blood from the placenta to the heart via the IVC. Forms the ductus venosus → later obliterated after birth to form the ligamentum teres hepatis.

questions.text: The embryonic origin of the ligamentum arteriosum is from the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The sixth arch is the pulmonary arch, from which pulmonary arteries are derived. On the left side, this arch maintains its connection with the dorsal aorta. In the fetus, this connection is patent and is called the ductus arteriosus.
  • After birth, when the lungs expand and pulmonary circulation begins, the ductus arteriosus closes functionally within hours and anatomically within weeks, becoming the ligamentum arteriosum.

choices.text: Persists as the membranous part of the interventricular septum
Becomes the upper segment of the muscular interventricular septum
Contributes to the formation of the left atrioventricular orifice

questions.text: The bulboventricular ridge of the embryonic heart:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The bulboventricular ridge is a transient muscular swelling at the junction between the primitive ventricle and the bulbus cordis.
  • It forms during the early looping of the heart tube (around day 23-28.
  • As the interventricular septum develops, there is incomplete partitioning between the primitive ventricle and the bulbus cordis, leaving a temporary communication called the interventricular foramen.
  • This bulboventricular foramen (a.k.a. primitive interventricular foramen) is bounded by the bulboventricular ridge.
  • As development continues:
    • The muscular septum grows upward.
    • The bulboventricular ridge disappears (or is resorbed) as part of the realignment of the outflow tract, allowing the membranous septum to close the foramen.

Explanation of Other Options:

Persists as the membranous part of the interventricular septum(Option A): The membranous part of the interventricular septum is formed by the fusion of the endocardial cushions, conotruncal ridges, and muscular septum, not the bulboventricular ridge.

Becomes the upper segment of the muscular interventricular septum(Option B): The muscular interventricular septum develops from myocardial proliferation in the primitive ventricles, while the bulboventricular ridge is resorbed during heart remodeling.

Contributes to the formation of the left atrioventricular orifice(Option C): The atrioventricular valves arise from the endocardial cushion tissue and mesenchyme of the AV canal, and the bulboventricular ridge has no role in valve formation.

choices.text: A decrease in pressure in the pleural cavities

questions.text: At birth, the following changes in circulation take place except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

At birth, the lungs fill with air, and the pressure in the pleural cavities begins to decline. Ductus venosus becomes ligamentum venosum. The ductus arteriosus closes and becomes the ligamentum arteriosum. Also, the foramen ovale closes and becomes the fossa ovalis.

Explanation of Other Options:

A decrease in pressure in the pleural cavities(Option A): When the newborn takes the first breath, the lungs expand, causing a drop in intrathoracic and pleural pressure, which facilitates pulmonary circulation.

Closure of the ductus venosus(Option B): The ductus venosus, which shunted oxygenated blood from the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava, closes functionally within hours and anatomically in a few days.

Closure of the ductus arteriosus(Option C): The ductus arteriosus, which connected the pulmonary artery to the aorta, closes functionally within 24-48 hours due to increased oxygen and reduced prostaglandins.

questions.text: In which week of development does the heart starts to beat?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The heart starts to beat in the 4th week of development.
  • The heart is the first functional organ to form in the embryo.
  • By day 22-23 (beginning of the 4th week), the heart tube begins to beat and pump blood, even before septation is complete.
  • Initially, this contraction is peristaltic, and coordination improves as development progresses.

choices.text: Non-fusion of the aortico-pulmonary septum with the truncus arteriosus
Anterior displacement of the aortico-pulmonary septum
Failure of the conotruncal ridge to fuse and descend
Aortico-pulmonary septum not following its spiral course

questions.text: A newborn developed cyanosis soon after birth. Chest X-ray showed the characteristic egg-on-a-string appearance. Which of the following mechanisms during embryonic development will most likely lead to the given condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The egg-on-a-string appearance on chest X-ray is characteristically seen in the transposition of great arteries (TGA).

It is considered to arise due to abnormal spiraling of the aortopulmonary septum (conotruncal septum).

Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA), a cyanotic congenital heart defect.

  • The egg-on-a-string appearance on chest X-ray refers to:
    • A narrow mediastinum (the string)
    • A globular heart (the egg), due to abnormal heart shape and great vessel position

Normally, the aortico-pulmonary septum spirals during development, allowing:

  • The aorta arises from the left ventricle, and
  • The pulmonary trunk arises from the right ventricle

In TGA, the aortico-pulmonary septum fails to spiral.

  • The aorta arises from the right ventricle
  • The pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle

Explanation of Other Options:

Non-fusion of aortico-pulmonary septum with truncus arteriosus(Option A): Leads to persistent truncus arteriosus.

Anterior displacement of the aortico-pulmonary septum(Option B): Seen in Tetralogy of Fallot. X-ray would be a boot-shaped heart

Failure of conotruncal ridge to fuse and descend(Option C): Causes truncus arteriosus or TOF

choices.text: Abnormal spiraling of the conotruncal septum
Failure in the formation of conotruncal ridges

questions.text: A newborn with persistent cyanosis was being evaluated. He was found to have a congenital heart disease that is schematically represented below. What is the most likely embryological defect causing this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given scenario is suggestive of persistent (patent) truncus arteriosus. Failure in the formation (absence) of conotruncal ridges leads to this condition.
  • The aortopulmonary septum is also known as the conotruncal septum. The formation of the aortopulmonary septum in the truncus arteriosus divides the outflow channel of the heart into the ventral aorta and the pulmonary trunk.
  • The conotruncal ridges (also called neural crest-derived truncal cushions) play a vital role in partitioning the outflow tract (truncus arteriosus and bulbus cordis) into:
    • The aorta
    • The pulmonary trunk

Explanation of Other Options:

Abnormal spiraling of the conotruncal septum(Option A): Leads to transposition of the great arteries (TGA)

Anterior displacement of conotruncal septum(Option C): Leads to tetralogy of Fallot

Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection(Option D): Failure of the common pulmonary vein to connect with the left atrium.

questions.text: Match the following fetal structures with their remnants:
The Tetralogy of Fallot includes the following defects of the heart:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The defects in the Tetralogy of Fallot are:

  • Pulmonary stenosis,
  • Ventricular septal defect,
  • Overriding the aorta, and
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy.

It results from abnormal conotruncal septation. Dexter, as in dextroposition, means right; sinister means left.

Clinical Features of Tetralogy of Fallot:

  • Cyanosis: This is the hallmark feature. It may not be apparent immediately at birth, but it typically develops in the first few months of life, especially during feeding, crying, or exertion.
  • Tet Spells (Hypercyanotic Episodes): These are sudden episodes of deep cyanosis, irritability, and possibly syncope. They often occur after crying or feeding due to increased right-to-left shunting. The child may squat instinctively during these episodes to increase systemic vascular resistance and reduce the shunt.
  • Clubbing of fingers and toes: Seen in older children due to chronic hypoxia.
  • Poor weight gain and fatigue: Due to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
  • Murmur: A harsh systolic ejection murmur is typically heard due to right ventricular outflow tract obstruction.
  • Squatting behavior: Common in toddlers; squatting increases peripheral resistance, which temporarily improves oxygenation by reducing the right-to-left shunt.

Investigations in Tetralogy of Fallot:

  • Chest X-ray (CXR): Shows the classic "boot-shaped heart" (coeur en sabot) due to right ventricular hypertrophy. There is also decreased pulmonary vascular markings (oligemia).
  • ECG (Electrocardiogram): Shows right axis deviation and right ventricular hypertrophy, which is consistent with the pressure overload on the right side of the heart.
  • Echocardiography: This is the gold standard investigation. It confirms the presence of the four classical defects - ventricular septal defect (VSD), pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy.
  • Oxygen challenge test: Typically shows minimal improvement in arterial oxygen saturation, confirming a fixed right-to-left shunt.

Explanation of Other Options:

Aortic stenosis(Option A): Not part of TOF. TOF involves pulmonary stenosis, not aortic stenosis.

Left ventricular hypertrophy(Option C): In TOF, the right ventricle undergoes hypertrophy due to outflow obstruction.

Atrial septal defect (Option D): The defect in TOF is a ventricular septal defect, not an ASD. Though ASD may be associated occasionally, it is not a core feature.

questions.text: Arrange the following structures of the primitive heart tube in cranial to caudal order.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The correct order of heart tube structures from cranial to caudal is bulbus cordis, primitive ventricle, primitive atrium, and the sinus venosus.
  • The 2 heart tubes formed in the cardiogenic area fuse, except at their caudal-most end, to become an inverted Y-shaped structure.
  • During this fusion, the central part of the heart tube expands to form the future outflow tract and ventricular regions.
  • The caudal pole of the tube receives the venous drainage, while the cranial end pumps out blood into the arterial system.
  • Truncus arteriosus: Gives rise to the aorta and pulmonary trunk
  • Bulbus cordis: Forms part of the ventricles and outflow tracts
  • Primitive ventricle: Forms the left ventricle
  • Primitive atrium: Forms both atria
  • Sinus venosus: Forms part of the right atrium and coronary sinus

questions.text: Which of the following forms the trabeculated part of the right ventricle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The trabeculated part of the right ventricle is formed from the proximal 1/3rd of the bulbus cordis.

The heart tube begins to bend by day 23. This bending creates the cardiac loop.

The bulbus cordis contributes to the formation of parts of the ventricles and the outflow tracts in the developing heart. It can be divided into three parts:

  • Proximal 1/3 of the bulbus cordis
    • Forms the trabeculated part of the right ventricle
    • This is the muscular inflow portion
  • Middle 1/3 (Conus cordis)(Option C ruled out)
    • Forms the smooth outflow tracts of both ventricles:
      • Conus arteriosus (right ventricle)
      • Aortic vestibule (left ventricle)
  • Distal 1/3 (Truncus arteriosus)(Option D ruled out)
    • Forms the roots and proximal portions of the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk

Explanation of Other Options:

Primitive ventricle(Option A): Forms the Trabeculated part of the left ventricle

questions.text: What is the location of the foramen secundum?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The foramen secundum (ostium secundum) is present at the upper part of the septum primum.
  • During fetal life, oxygenated blood reaches the right atrium from the placenta. This blood then reaches the left atrium through the gap between the atria.
  • The initial gap is the foramen primum formed at the lower end of the septum primum.
  • Before the foramen primum is closed, another path has to be created for the flow of blood. This gap is the foramen secundum at the upper part of the septum primum.

Explanation of Other Options:

Upper part of septum secundum(Option A) This forms the foramen ovale, not foramen secundum.

Lower part of septum primum(Option B): This region closes the foramen primum.

Lower part of septum secundum(Option D): Not involved in foramen secundum formation.

questions.text: The Sinus venosus does not receive blood from which of the following veins?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The sinus venosus does not receive blood from the subcardinal veins. They are found on the urogenital ridges and mainly drain the developing kidney.

They are not part of the early venous inflow into the sinus venosus.
Instead, subcardinal veins develop later and contribute to the formation of:

  • Renal veins
  • Gonadal veins
  • A segment of the inferior vena cava (IVC)

Sinus venosus is the caudal-most part of the tubular heart and has right and left horns. Each horn of the sinus venosus has 3 branches:

  • The vitelline vein receives blood from the yolk sac(Option A ruled out)
  • The umbilical vein receives blood from the placenta(Option B ruled out)
  • The common cardinal vein receives blood from the body wall(Option C ruled out)

questions.text: From where is the membranous part of the interventricular septum derived?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structure marked is the membranous part of the interventricular septum. It is derived from endocardial cushions.

Endocardial cushions are soft tissue masses that protrude into the atrioventricular and conotruncal regions.

  • Atrioventricular cushions are derived from overlying endocardial cells.
  • The conotruncal cushions are derived from the neural crest cells.

Endocardial cushions contribute to the formation of:

  • Atrial septa
  • Ventricular septum (membranous portion)
  • Atrioventricular canals
  • Atrioventricular valves
  • Aortic and pulmonary channels

The interventricular septum has two parts:

  1. Muscular part
    • Grows upward from the primitive ventricular floor
    • Forms most of the septum
  2. Membranous part
    • Closes the interventricular foramen
    • Derived from three embryological structures:
      • Endocardial cushions
      • Right and left bulbar ridges (from conotruncal swellings)
      • Dorsal part of the interventricular septum

Explanation of Other Options:

Left venous valve(Option A): Contributes to the formation of part of the interatrial septum (specifically, the valve of the IVC and the coronary sinus)

Septum primum(Option C): Involved in interatrial septum formation, not interventricular

Bulbus cordis(Option D): Bulbus cordis, which forms parts of the ventricles and outflow tracts, but not the membranous septum

questions.text: Of the following, the one most closely associated with the portal vein is: Options:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The portal vein is primarily derived from the vitelline veins, which drain blood from the yolk sac during early embryonic development. These veins form a plexus around the duodenum, and through a complex remodeling process, parts of the vitelline veins persist to form the portal venous system, including:

  • Portal vein
  • Superior mesenteric vein
  • Part of the splenic vein

Explanation of Other Options:

Umbilical vein( Option A):

  • Brings oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus
  • It eventually forms the ligamentum teres hepatis, but does not form the portal vein

Umbilical artery( Option B):

  • Carries deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta
  • Eventually becomes the medial umbilical ligament

3rd aortic arch( Option D):

  • Contributes to the formation of the common carotid arteries and the proximal internal carotid arteries
  • Not related to portal venous development

questions.text: The least serious clinical problems can be expected from which of the following cardiac abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the case of dextrocardia, there is transposition so that the heart and great vessels are mirror images of normal.
  • This is a benign situation that is often accompanied by transposition of abdominal viscera, as well.
  • As long as there are no other defects, the patient may never notice the abnormality.

Dextrocardia simply refers to the heart being located on the right side of the chest instead of the left. It may be of two types:

  • Isolated dextrocardia (without situs inversus or other heart defects):
    • Rare, but can sometimes occur with no significant functional defect.
    • Can be asymptomatic and found incidentally.
  • Dextrocardia with situs inversus totalis:
    • Often benign when there's a complete mirror-image reversal of all visceral organs.
    • May be associated with Kartagener syndrome (if ciliary dysfunction is present), but even then, cardiac function is usually preserved.
  • Dextrocardia with congenital heart defects (e.g., TGA, TOF, single ventricle):
    • These forms are severe and symptomatic.

Explanation of Other Options:

Patent ductus arteriosus(Option A): Can cause pulmonary hypertension, heart failure, especially if large.

Mitral valve stenosis(Option B): Often leads to significant morbidity due to congestive symptoms, atrial fibrillation, and even thromboembolic events.

Atrial septal defect(Option C): Commonly mild but can lead to heart failure, arrhythmias, or stroke due to paradoxical embolism.

choices.text: All of the above are correct

questions.text: In tricuspid atresia, there is usually:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tricuspid atresia:

  • In this condition, there is complete agenesis of the tricuspid valves.
  • It is caused by an insufficient amount of tissue in the AV cushion for the formation of the tricuspid valve.
  • The tricuspid atresias are always associated with
    • Patent foramen ovale(Option A)
    • VSD(Option B)
    • Underdeveloped right ventricle(Option C)
    • Hypertrophy of the right ventricle

choices.text: A patent foramen ovale is the only outlet for blood from the right side of the heart
The right ventricle is markedly underdeveloped
A patent ductus arteriosus offers a route of blood flow to the lungs

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT characterize atresia of the valve of the pulmonary artery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Overriding of the aorta is not seen in pulmonary valve atresia

  • When the pulmonary valve is atretic, the only way for blood to get out of the right side is via a patent foramen ovale. (Option A ruled out.)
  • Conversely, the only way for blood to get to the lungs is via the patent ductus arteriosus. (Option C ruled ou)
  • Because the right ventricle is not pumping blood, it becomes markedly hypoplastic. (Option B ruled out) There is no overriding aorta.

Pulmonary valve atresia is a congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary valve fails to form properly, resulting in no direct blood flow from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery.

choices.text: Is characterized by a large opening between left and right atria
May be caused by excessive resorption of septum primum
May be caused by inadequate development of septum secundum
All of the above are correct

questions.text: Ostium secundum defect:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • An ostium secundum defect is a large opening between the atria that can be caused either by excessive resorption of the septum primum or inadequate development of the septum secundum.
  • Depending on the size of the defect, there can be shunting of blood between the atria.
  • The septum primum initially grows downward from the roof of the primitive atrium to fuse with the endocardial cushions.
  • Before fusion, it leaves a temporary gap (foramen primum), which eventually closes.
  • Meanwhile, apoptosis in the upper septum primum creates the foramen secundum. ( Option B ruled out)
  • The septum secundum then forms to the right of the septum primum and normally overlaps the foramen secundum to form the foramen ovale.

Explanation of Other Options:

It is characterized by a large opening between the left and right atria(Option A): This defect allows blood to shunt from the left atrium to the right atrium, causing volume overload on the right side and pulmonary overcirculation.

May be caused by excessive resorption of the septum primum(Option B): If the septum primum develops perforations that are too large or resorbs excessively, it leaves an abnormally large foramen secundum, leading to an ASD.

May be caused by inadequate development of the septum secundum(Option C): If the septum secundum is too short or poorly developed, it may fail to overlap the foramen secundum, again resulting in persistent communication between atria.

choices.text: A) The coronary sinus is formed from the left horn of the sinus venosus
B) The oblique vein of the left atrium is derived from the left posterior cardinal vein
The valve of the coronary sinus is formed from the left sinus valve
The valve of the inferior vena cava is formed from the left sinus valve

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the embryological development of venous structures in the heart is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The left horn of the sinus venosus forms coronary sinus, and the left common cardinal vein becomes the oblique vein of the left atrium.

The right sinus valve becomes the valve of the coronary sinus and the valve of the inferior vena cava.

The left sinus valve becomes part of the interatrial septum.
Sinus Venosus:

Initially, it has right and left horns, each receiving blood from:

  • Vitelline vein
  • Umbilical vein
  • Common cardinal vein

Explanation of Other Options: 

The oblique vein of the left atrium is derived from the left posterior cardinal vein(Option B): It is derived from the left common cardinal vein

The valve of the coronary sinus develops from the left sinus valve(Option C): It is derived from the right sinus valve.

The valve of the inferior vena cava is derived from the left sinus valve(Option D): Also from the right sinus valve, not the left.

choices.text: The left atrium and left ventricle are hyperplastic, or overdeveloped
Blood passes into the aorta through a patent ductus arteriosus
Blood fails to reach the descending aorta

questions.text: With aortic valvular atresia:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • For a patient with an atretic aortic semilunar valve to survive, there must be a patent ductus arteriosus so that blood can reach the systemic circulation.
  • Because the left ventricle is unable to pump, it is hypo
  • Aortic valvular atresia is a congenital heart defect in which the aortic valve fails to develop or open, causing severe obstruction to outflow from the left ventricle into the aorta.

Explanation of Other Options:

The left atrium and left ventricle are hyperplastic, or overdeveloped(Option A):

  • In aortic atresia, blood cannot exit the left ventricle, leading to hypoplasia (underdevelopment) of the left ventricle and often the mitral valve and aortic arch.
  • This condition is a part of hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS).

There is an overriding aorta(Option B):

  • An overriding aorta is a key feature of Tetralogy of Fallot, not aortic atresia.
  • In aortic atresia, the aorta is often hypoplastic or dependent on retrograde flow from PDA.

Blood fails to reach the descending aorta(Option D): Blood does reach the descending aorta, but via the PDA, not through the normal left ventricular route.

choices.text: Secundum type atrial septal defect, or ASD

questions.text: The most common type of cardiac septal defect is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Although the most common atrial septal defect is the secundum type ASD,
  • The most common cardiac septal defect is the Muscular type ventricular septal defect

Ventricular Septal Defects (VSDs)

  • VSDs are the most common congenital cardiac malformation, occurring in approximately 12 per 10,000 births.
  • They can affect either the membranous or muscular portions of the interventricular septum.

Hemodynamic Consequences:

  • The left-to-right shunt causes increased pulmonary blood flow.
  • In significant cases, pulmonary artery flow may be 1.2 to 1.7 times the systemic (aortic) flow.

Clinical Note: Membranous VSDs may be part of complex anomalies like Tetralogy of Fallot or truncus arteriosus, due to failure in conotruncal septum development.

choices.text: A-4, B-6, C-3, D-5, E-1, F-2
A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4, E-5, F-6
A-5, B-6, C-4, D-1, E-3, F-2
A-1, B-2, C-6, D-3, E-4, F-5

questions.text: Match the adult vascular structure (Column A) with its embryological origin (Column B):
questions.solution: Explanation:

choices.text: It lies immediately distal to the primitive ventricles
It connects to the dorsal aorta via the aortic arch arteries
It persists as the semilunar valve region in the adult heart
It is synonymous with the truncus arteriosus

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the aortic sac is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The aortic sac receives blood from the truncus arteriosus and sends it into the aortic arch arteries, which branch from it and connect it to the paired dorsal aortae.
  • The aortic sac becomes the proximal part of the aortic arch & the brachiocephalic trunk.

Explanation of Other Options:

It lies immediately distal to the primitive ventricles(Option A): The structure immediately distal to the primitive ventricles is the bulbus cordis, followed by the truncus arteriosus and then the aortic sac. So, the aortic sac is not immediately distal to the ventricles.

It persists as the semilunar valve region in the adult heart(Option C): The semilunar valves (aortic and pulmonary) develop at the junction of the bulbus cordis and truncus arteriosus, not from the aortic sac.

It is synonymous with the truncus arteriosus(Option D): Although closely related embryologically, the aortic sac is a separate structure distal to the truncus arteriosus. It acts as a transitional chamber from which the arch arteries emerge.

choices.text: Right horn of the sinus venosus
Left horn of the sinus venosus
Right cusp of the valve of the sinus venosus

questions.text: The crista terminalis is derived from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The crista terminalis is a ridge inside the right atrium that marks the junction between the smooth-walled part (derived from the right horn of the sinus venosus) and the trabeculated part (from the primitive atrium). It acts as a landmark internally, corresponding externally to the sulcus terminalis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Left horn of the sinus venosus(Option B): The left horn of the sinus venosus becomes the coronary sinus, not the crista terminalis.

Primitive atrium(Option C): The primitive atrium forms the trabeculated part (auricles) of both right and left atria, not the smooth portion or the crista terminalis.

Right cusp of the valve of the sinus venosus(OptionD): The right and left venous valves of the sinus venosus contribute to structures like the valve of the IVC and valve of the coronary sinus, but not to the crista terminalis.

choices.text: The epimyocardial layer of the heart
Dorsal mesocardium over the sinus venosus

questions.text: The epicardium forms from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The epimyocardial layer of the developing heart develops from the splanchnic mesoderm between the heart tubes and the intraembryonic coelom in the cardiogenic area.
  • The part of the epimyocardium that lines this region of the coelom becomes visceral serous pericardium, while the mesoderm between this and the heart tubes becomes myocardium.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dorsal mesocardium over the sinus venosus(Option B): While the dorsal mesocardium plays a role in suspending the heart tube and contributes to other nearby structures, the epicardium is not directly formed from it. However, the proepicardial organ, from which the epicardium arises, is located near the dorsal mesocardium.

Cardiogenic plate mesoderm(Option C): The cardiogenic plate mesoderm gives rise to the endocardium, myocardium, and heart tube components, but not the epicardium directly.

The endocardium(Option D): The endocardium lines the inside of the heart chambers and arises from splanchnic mesoderm, not the outer epicardium.

questions.text: Which of the following structures ruptures to create the transverse pericardial sinus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The transverse pericardial sinus forms when the middle part of the dorsal mesocardium disappears during heart development.
  • This creates a communication between the right and left sides of the pericardial cavity, forming a tunnel behind the aorta and pulmonary trunk, and in front of the superior vena cava and left atrium.

Explanation of Other Options:

Septum primum(Option A): This is involved in interatrial septum formation, not pericardial sinus formation. Its rupture contributes to the foramen secundum, not the transverse sinus.

Septum secundum (Option B): Also contributes to interatrial septum development and the foramen ovale, not the pericardial sinuses.

Truncus arteriosus(Option D): This gives rise to the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk. It has no role in forming the pericardial sinuses.
